abstract.para: This document provides answers to frequently asked questions (faq) about Orocos installation, configuration and usage.

question.para: What is Orocos?

answer.para: Orocos stands for Open Robot Control Software and is a library for writing hard realtime control applications in C++. It supports hard realtime RTAI/LXRT and non realtime GNU/Linux programs. Take a look at the webpage for Orocos history and the main page for a high level overview.

question.para: Where can I find the latest Orocos documentation?

answer.para: In the Documentation Section of the Orocos website, you can find all online documents (and this FAQ). Also, the Download Section contains separate manuals for all software packages.

question.para: Where can I find download and installation instructions?

answer.para:
In the Download Section of the Orocos website and the
Orocos Installation Manual.

question.para: Where can I find the software manuals?

answer.para: In the Download Section of the Orocos website. An all in one manual is available too ( The Complete Orocos Software Manual ).

question.para: Where can I ask Orocos software related questions (even newbie questions) ?

answer.para: On the Orocos-dev mailinglist (medium traffic).

question.para: Where can I ask Orocos 'philosophical' questions ?

answer.para: On the Orocos mailinglist ( low traffic ).

question.para: Where can I find the latest configuration instructions?

answer.para: In the Orocos Installation Manual.

question.para: Which Linux version should I use?

answer.para: Orocos works with vanilla Linux 2.4 and 2.6 kernels.

question.para: Which RTAI version should I use?

answer.para: Orocos works with RTAI 3.0r4 ( you need to apply a patch ) and RTAI 3.1 (no patch).

question.para: How should I configure my Linux Kernel?

answer.para:
The following Linux options must be disabled to guarantee the most stable performance :
Disable APM / ACPI. These can interfere with scheduling and RTAI.
Disable MTRR. This can interfere when using RTAI.

The follwing Linux options must be enabled to guarantee the most stable performance :
Enable your USB driver ( or disable USB in your BIOS ). The aim of using a Linux USB driver is to disable the BIOS USB driver.
Enable your IDE chipset and choose the correct CPU. Wrong settings for one of these will cause lock-ups.

question.para: How should I configure RTAI?

answer.para:
The follwing RTAI options must be enabled (and modules must be loaded) :
LXRT scheduler (rtai_hal+rtai_lxrt)
Semaphores (rtai_sem)
FPU Support
RealTime Memory Manager (with vmalloc)

question.para: How can I change which files get compiled in Orocos ?

answer.para: Use make configure_packages in your build directory , which will popup the configuration GUI. If you unload packages (see also Build->Packages...) they will no longer be compiled (without removing them physically).

question.para: What are the system requirements of Orocos?

answer.para: For compiling Orocos, you need a very fast machine with minimum 256MB RAM, and 512MB RAM to be comfortable.

For running an Orocos application, you need an Intel Pentium Processor with minimum 32MB RAM, but much depends on the application itself. Orocos has not been tested on other (PowerPC, ARM,...) processors, but an FPU unit is surely needed.

question.para: The first message I get is 'Segmentation fault' !

answer.para: Check if your rtai_lxrt and rtai_sem kernel modules are loaded.

question.para: The first message I get is 'LXRT NOT INITIALISED IN THIS THREAD pid=1234, BUT TRIES TO INVOKE LXRT FUNCTION >>rtos_mutex_init<< ANYWAY'. What did I do wrong ?

answer.para: You tried to use RTAI's functions while RTAI was not yet initialised. This happens if you use global objects which contain Mutexes. Examples are ORO_CoreLib::Event and some DataObjects, Buffers and the Logger class. The solution is not to use global objects, but use global pointers and create the objects in ORO_main() with new.
You did not put your program in the ORO_main() function. ( see The Installation Manual and The Orocos OS Manual. )

question.para: The realtime performance is Terrible !

answer.para: Well, that is not a question really, but anyway... Did you read the section about Priority Inversions in the Orocos CoreLib Manual ?
Are you calling Linux system calls from a hard-realtime thread ? See this document for what you can and can't do within hard-realtime LXRT tasks.

question.para: make check crashes my system. What did I do wrong ?

answer.para: The Orocos testcases test the system to its limits and may crash RTAI if not properly configured. Especially RTAI 3.0 and older.

question.para: The Control Kernel architecture does not fit my application. So is Orocos useless for me ?

answer.para: No, the Control Kernel is designed for flexible realtime feedback control. If that does not fit your application, take a look at the Realtime Task Infrastructure and all surrounding documents to map your realtime tasks into Orocos.

question.para: Don't you have a shorter document than the 150 pages manual ?

answer.para: We have, but it tells completely different things.

question.para: What is the overhead of all this C++, can it be Realtime ?

answer.para:
C++ is a fundamental pillar of Orocos' design. If need to be convinced that this actually works, take a look at
Demonstration movies , and read a Technical Report on C++ Performance , but Google can point you to lots more documents. We are still finding ways to measure the overhead of using Orocos itself, and much depends on the application, but the minimum system requirements to run it are a Pentium processor with 32 MB of RAM.

For questions related to the use of the Orocos Software, please consult these web pages and the Orocos manuals. If that fails, the orocos-dev@mail.mech.kuleuven.ac.be mailing list might help.
